summary: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] (Japanese: 大坂 なおみ, Hepburn: Ōsaka Naomi, Japanese pronunciation: [oːsaka naomi], born October 16, 1997) is a Japanese professional tennis player. [0] has been ranked world No. 1 in singles by the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) and is the first Asian player to hold the top ranking in singles. [0] is a four-time Grand Slam singles champion, with two Australian Open and two US Open titles. [0]'s seven titles on the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) also include two at the Premier Mandatory level. At the 2018 US Open and the 2019 Australian Open, [0] won [0]'s first two major titles in back-to-back tournaments. [0] was the first woman to win successive major singles titles since Serena Williams in 2015, and the first to win her first two in successive majors since Jennifer Capriati in 2001.Born in Japan to a Haitian-American father and a Japanese mother, [0] has lived and trained in the United States since age three. [0] came to prominence at age 16 when [0] defeated former US Open champion Samantha Stosur in [0]'s the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Tour debut at the 2014 Stanford Classic. Two years later, [0] reached [0]'s first the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) final at the 2016 Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo to enter the top 50 of the the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) rankings. [0] made [0]'s breakthrough into the upper echelon of women's tennis in 2018 when [0] won [0]'s first the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) title at the Indian Wells Open. Later in 2018, [0] defeated Serena Williams in the final of the 2018 US Open to become the first Japanese player to win a major singles title. In mid-2021, suffering from depression and other issues, [0] retired from the French Open, dropped out of Wimbledon, and lost early at the 2018 US Open. [0] closed down the rest of [0]'s tennis season to focus on family and health. From 2018 to 2021, [0] won a major singles title in four consecutive years, with [0]'s streak ending in [0] is one of the world's's most marketable athletes, having been ranked eighth among all athletes in endorsement income in 2020. [0] was also the highest-earning female athlete of all time by annual income 2020. [0] has gained significant recognition as an activist, having showcased support for the Black Lives Matter movement in conjunction with [0]'s matches. [0] was named one of the 2020 Sports Illustrated Sportspersons of the Year for [0]'s activism largely as part of [0]'s US Open championship run, and was also included on Time's annual list of the 100 most influential people in the world's in 2019, 2020 and 2021. Moreover, [0] was the 2021 Laureus World Sportswoman of the Year. At the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, [0] became the first tennis player to light the Olympic cauldron during the opening ceremony. On the court, [0] has an aggressive playing style with a powerful serve that can reach 201 kilometers per hour (125 mph).

Early life and background: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was born on October 16, 1997, in Chūō-ku, Osaka in Japan to Tamaki Osaka (大坂 環, Ōsaka Tamaki) and Leonard François. Her mother is from Nemuro, Hokkaido, Japan, and her father is from Jacmel, Haiti. [0] has an older sister, Mari, who is a former professional tennis player. The sisters were given Her mother's family name for practical reasons when the family lived in Japan. Tamaki Osaka (大坂 環, Ōsaka Tamaki) and Leonard François met when her father was visiting Hokkaido while her father was a college student in New York.When [0] was three years old, the family moved from Japan to Elmont, New York on Long Island to live with her father's parents. her father was inspired to teach her father's how to play tennis by watching the Williams sisters compete at the 1999 French Open. Having little experience as a tennis player her father, her father sought to emulate how Richard Williams trained Richard Williams's to become two of the best players in the world, despite having never played tennis. her father remarked that "the blueprint was already there. her father just had to follow the blueprint," with regard to the detailed plan Richard Williams had developed for Richard Williams's . her father began coaching The sisters an older sister, Mari, who is a former professional tennis player once the family settled in the United States. In 2006, the family moved to Florida when [0] was eight or nine years old so that the family would have better opportunities to train. [0] practiced on the Pembroke Pines public courts during the day and was homeschooled at night. When [0] was 15 years old, [0] began working with Patrick Tauma at the ISP Academy. In 2014, [0] moved to the Harold Solomon Tennis Academy. [0] later trained at the ProWorld Tennis Academy.Although [0] was raised in the United States, Tamaki Osaka (大坂 環, Ōsaka Tamaki) and Leonard François decided that Tamaki Osaka (大坂 環, Ōsaka Tamaki) and Leonard François's would represent Japan. Tamaki Osaka (大坂 環, Ōsaka Tamaki) and Leonard François said, "Tamaki Osaka (大坂 環, Ōsaka Tamaki) and Leonard François made the decision that [0] would represent Japan at an early age. [0] was born in Osaka in Japan and was brought up in a household of Japanese and Haitian culture. Quite simply, The sisters an older sister, Mari, who is a former professional tennis player have always felt Japanese so felt was Tamaki Osaka (大坂 環, Ōsaka Tamaki) and Leonard François's only rationale. It was never a financially motivated decision nor were Tamaki Osaka (大坂 環, Ōsaka Tamaki) and Leonard François ever swayed either way by any national federation." decided may have also been motivated by a lack of interest from the United States Tennis Association (USTA) when [0] was still a young player. the United States Tennis Association (USTA) later offered [0] the opportunity to train at the United States Tennis Association (USTA)'s national training center in Boca Raton, Florida when [0] was 16 years old, but [0] declined.

Professional career.2011\u20132015: First WTA Tour match win: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] never competed on the ITF Junior Circuit, the premier international junior tour, and only played in a small number of junior tournaments at any age level. [0] instead skipped to the ITF Women's Circuit and played [0]'s first qualifying match in October 2011 on [0]'s 14th birthday. [0] then made [0]'s professional main-draw debut in doubles at [0]'s next tournament in March with her sister Mari. Meanwhile, [0] did not qualify for [0]'s first singles main draw until July in [0]'s seventh such attempt. [0]'s best result of the 2012 season came at a $10k event in Amelia Island, where [0] lost to her sister Mari in the semifinals. [0] has never won a title at the ITF level, only managing to finish runner-up on four occasions. [0]'s first two finals came at the $25K level, one of which was in June 2013 in El Paso, Texas. The other was in March 2014 in Irapuato, Mexico and included a victory over her sister Mari.In September 2013, [0] turned professional shortly before turning 16 years old. [0] entered [0] first two qualifying draws on the WTA Tour September 2013 at the Challenge Bell in Quebec and the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo. the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo was [0]'s first opportunity to compete professionally in Japan. The following summer, [0] qualified for [0]'s first the WTA Tour main draw at the 2014 Stanford Classic. In [0]'s tour level debut, [0] upset world No. 19, Samantha Stosur, in a tight match where [0] saved a match point in the second set tiebreak and came back from a 5–3 deficit in the third set. [0] was still just 16 years old and ranked No. 406 at the time. [0] also won a match as a wildcard at the Japan Women's Open, [0]'s only other the WTA Tour main draw of the year. These victories helped [0]'s progress into the top 250 of the rankings before the end of the year.Despite not winning another the WTA Tour main-draw singles match in 2015, [0] continued to climb up the rankings. [0] reached [0]'s two highest level finals, the first at the $75k Kangaroo Cup in Japan and the second at the $50k Surbiton Trophy in England. Following these runner-up results, [0] was ranked high enough to enter qualifying at the last two Grand Slam singles events of the year, Wimbledon and the US Open. [0] won [0]'s first match at the US Open, but was unable to qualify for either main draw. Nonetheless, [0] had a strong finish to the year. In October during the the WTA Tour Finals, [0] won the Rising Stars Invitational four-player exhibition tournament, defeating heavy favorite and world No. 35, Caroline Garcia, in the final. Continuing to play in November, [0] then reached the biggest final of [0]'s career at the WTA 125 Hua Hin Championships in Thailand. After a semifinal at a $75k event in Japan, [0] finished the year ranked No. 144.
Professional career.2016: Newcomer of the Year, top 50: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] began the season playing three tournaments in Australia. [0]'s results during this stretch were good enough to bring [0] near the top 100, which allowed [0] to play in WTA Tour-level events all year. Most notably, [0] qualified for [0]'s first Grand Slam main draw at the Australian Open and made it to the third round. In particular, [0] upset No. 21, Elina Svitolina, in straight sets in the second round before losing to No. 16, Victoria Azarenka. Back in the United States, [0] received a wildcard into the Miami Open, her first Premier Mandatory main draw. During the Miami Open, her first Premier Mandatory main draw, [0] won two matches including a victory over No. 18, Sara Errani. With this success, [0] progressed into the top 100 of the WTA rankings for the first time.In the clay-court events leading up to the French Open, [0] needed to qualify for every event [0] entered. [0] only managed to do so at a single event, the Charleston Open, where [0] lost [0] only match in the main draw. Nonetheless, [0] was ranked high enough to be directly accepted into the main draw of the French Open. In [0]'s debut at the French Open, [0] recorded [0] only two clay-court match wins of the season. [0] also won the first set against No. 6 Simona Halep, but ultimately lost the first set against No. 6 Simona Halep. [0] then did not play the grass-court season after suffering an injury shortly after the French Open.[0] returned to tennis in the middle of July. At the US Open in August, [0] reached the third round at a major event for the third time that year. [0] upset No. 30 CoCo Vandeweghe in the first round before losing to No. 9 Madison Keys, in three sets. During [0]'s match against No. 9 Madison Keys, [0] had a 5–1 lead in the third set before ultimately losing in a tiebreak. After the US Open in August, [0] began the Asian hardcourt season with two tournaments in Tokyo, first losing in the second round at the Japan Women's Open. Having already reached [0]'s first two career WTA quarterfinals earlier in the year, [0] then made [0]'s breakthrough as a wildcard at the Premier-level Pan Pacific Open. [0] upset No. 12 Dominika Cibulková and No. 20 Svitolina on the road to making [0] first WTA final at the age of 18. At the time, No. 12 Dominika Cibulková was the highest-ranked player [0] ever defeated. Additionally, [0] was the first Japanese player to contest the final at the Premier-level Pan Pacific Open since Kimiko Date in 1995. [0] ultimately finished runner-up to Caroline Wozniacki. Nonetheless, [0] entered the top 50 of the WTA rankings for the first time. At the end of the season, [0] was named the WTA Newcomer of the Year.
Professional career.2017: Two top-10 victories: [0] is our person to focus on. After [0]'s huge improvement the previous year, [0] was unable to set a new career-high ranking in 2017. Nonetheless, [0] maintained a steady ranking throughout 2017, rising no higher than No. 44 while falling no lower than No. 68, [0]'s year-end ranking. [0] did not win more than two main draw matches at any event 2017.[0]'s best tournament result of 2017 came at the Canadian Open, where she reached the round of sixteen as a qualifier. During the Canadian Open, where she reached the round of sixteen as a qualifier, [0] upset No. 16 Anastasija Sevastova before needing to retire against world No. 1, Karolína Plíšková, due to an abdominal injury. [0] had won the second set against world No. 1, Karolína Plíšková. [0]'s next best results of 2017 came at the last two major events of 2017, where [0] made it to the third round at each of Wimbledon and the US Open. [0] had a strong debut at Wimbledon, upsetting No. 23 Barbora Strýcová, before losing to No. 11 Venus Williams. the US Open was then highlighted by [0]'s first-round win against defending champion and No. 6, Angelique Kerber, the first top-ten victory of [0]'s career. However, [0]'s run was ended by veteran qualifier Kaia Kanepi. This was the second consecutive year [0] lost in the third round of the US Open, after having at least a one-break lead in the third set.[0] in particular struggled to play on clay courts. After winning [0]'s first two matches at the Charleston Open, [0] did not win another main-draw match on clay the remainder of 2017. [0] did well in [0]'s first full grass-court season on the WTA Tour, going 4–4 behind [0]'s performance at Wimbledon. [0]'s biggest wins of 2017 all came on hardcourt. In addition to [0]'s results at the Canadian Open, where she reached the round of sixteen as a qualifier and the US Open, [0] also recorded a second top-ten victory over No. 5, Venus Williams, at the Hong Kong Open, [0]'s last tournament of 2017.
Professional career.2018: US Open champion, world No. 4: [0] is our person to focus on. Following [0]'s lack of improvement in 2017, [0] hired Sascha Bajin to be [0]'s coach in the off-season. In their second tournament together, [0] produced [0]'s career best result at a major event. At the Australian Open, [0] reached the fourth round after defeating two top-20 players in Elena Vesnina and hometown favorite Ashleigh Barty, ultimately losing to world No. 1, Simona Halep. reached helped [0] return to the top 50 within the next month.At the Indian Wells Open, [0] had the next big breakthrough of her career. Having never won a professional title or made it past the third round at a Premier Mandatory event, [0] won the Indian Wells Open convincingly, only dropping one set in the middle round of the tournament. In the quarterfinals and semifinals, [0] defeated two top-five opponents in Karolína Plíšková and world No. 1, Simona Halep, the latter of which was [0]'s first victory over a current No. 1 player. [0] then closed out the Indian Wells Open with a win in the final over fellow up-and-coming player Daria Kasatkina, making [0] the youngest champion at the Indian Wells Open in ten years. With [0]'s first title, [0] surged past [0]'s previous career-high ranking to No. 22 in the world. [0] played the following week as well at the Miami Open and extended [0]'s win streak by one additional match in [0]'s first meeting against her childhood idol, Serena Williams, who was competing in just her second tournament back from maternity leaveher childhood idol, Serena Williams, who was competing in just her second tournament back from maternity leave's .After [0]'s success in the early months of the season, [0] had a rather quiet middle of the year. [0] reached the third round at both the French Open and Wimbledon, matching [0]'s best performance at each tournament. The closest [0] came to winning another tournament was on grass at the Nottingham Open, where [0] lost to hometown favorite Ashleigh Barty in the semifinals.[0] did not have another breakthrough result until the US Open, where she won her second title of the year. Like at the Indian Wells Open, [0] only dropped one set in the middle round of the tournamentthe US Open, where she won her second title of the year, this time to No. 20 Aryna Sabalenka. In the three early rounds, [0] only lost a total of seven games and notably recorded a double bagel victory against Aliaksandra Sasnovich. [0] was drawn against Madison Keys in the semifinals, and was able to avenge [0]'s tough loss from the 2016 US Open to advance to the final. In the final, [0] defeated Serena Williams for the second time in 2018 to win [0]'s first major title. The match was marred by an on-court dispute between Serena Williams and the umpire highlighted by Serena Williams receiving a game penalty. Boos from the crowd continued during The match and the award ceremony. [0] later said that defeated was "a little bit bittersweet" and "defeated wasn't necessarily the happiest memory." Nonetheless, [0] became the first Japanese woman to contest a major singles final and the first Japanese Grand Slam singles champion.Now ranked in the top ten, [0] extended [0]'s win streak to ten matches by reaching the final at the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo for the second time in her career. Karolína Plíšková was able to end Karolína Plíšková's win streak in the final. [0] then reached the semifinals at the Premier Mandatory China Open. With [0]'s third consecutive deep run, [0] rose to a career-best ranking of world No. 4, matching the record of Kimiko Date and Kei Nishikori for the highest ranking held by a Japanese player in history. [0] closed out 2018 by participating at the WTA Finals, where [0] was grouped with Sloane Stephens, Angelique Kerber, and Kiki Bertens. [0] lost all three of [0]'s round-robin matches, notably retiring against Kiki Bertens due to a hamstring injury to end [0]'s season. [0] finished 2018 as the WTA Tour leader in prize money, having earned almost $6.4 million.
Professional career.2019: Australian Open title, world No. 1: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] entered the Australian Open as the fourth seed and also one of eleven players in contention for the world No. 1 ranking. [0] made it to the final against Petra Kvitová, having beaten Hsieh Su-wei in the third round despite being one set, 2–4 and 0–40 down at one point. Anastasija Sevastova also won the first set against [0] in the fourth round, while No. 8 Karolína Plíšková pushed [0] to three sets in the semifinals. After [0] won the first set in the final, Petra Kvitová saved three championship points before breaking [0] in back-to-back service games to win the second set. Nonetheless, [0] recovered to win the championship. [0] was the first woman to win consecutive major singles titles since Serena Williams in 2015, and was the first player to follow up her first Grand Slam singles title with another at the next such event since Jennifer Capriati in 2001. [0] also became the first Asian player to be ranked No. 1 in the world in singles. Despite the championship, [0] parted ways with [0]'s coach Sascha Bajin following the Australian Open.[0] struggled after the Australian Open. [0] lost in the fourth and third rounds at the two Premier Mandatory tournaments in March, the Indian Wells Open and the Miami Open. After beginning the clay-court season with a semifinal at the Stuttgart Grand Prix where [0] withdrew due to an abdominal injury, [0]'s best results were two quarterfinals at the Madrid Open and the Italian Open. [0] also withdrew from the Italian Open due to a right hand injury. [0] matched [0]'s best result at the French Open, losing to Kateřina Siniaková in the third round. During the grass-court season, [0] lost in the early rounds to Yulia Putintseva at both tournaments [0] entered, including the first round at Wimbledon. As a result, [0] lost the No. 1 ranking to Ashleigh Barty.Before the US Open, [0] made the quarterfinals at the two Premier 5 tournaments in August, the Canadian Open and the Cincinnati Open, where [0] was defeated by Serena Williams and Sofia Kenin respectively. These performances helped [0] regain the No. 1 ranking so that [0] had the top seed at the US Open. Nonetheless, [0]'s title defense came to an end in the fourth round against Belinda Bencic, who defeated [0] for the third time during the year. [0] then fell to No. 4 in the world. Following the Australian Open, [0] went back to having [0]'s father as [0]'s coach. went had an immediate impact, as [0] won [0] next two tournaments. First, [0] won the Pan Pacific Open in [0]'s hometown of Osaka, defeating Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova in the final. Two weeks later, [0] won the Premier Mandatory China Open. During the Premier Mandatory China Open, [0] defeated reigning US Open champion Bianca Andreescu in the quarterfinals and world No. 1 and reigning French Open champion Ashleigh Barty in the final, both in three sets after losing the first. losing was reigning US Open champion Bianca Andreescu's first loss since March. These results brought [0] to No. 3 in the world. At the end of the season, [0] qualified for the WTA Finals for the second consecutive year. However, after defeating Petra Kvitová in [0]'s first match, [0] withdrew due to injury.
Professional career.2020: Second US Open title: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] only played four tournaments in 2020, largely due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Before the tour shutdown, [0] lost to No. 2 Karolína Plíšková in a semifinal at the Brisbane International and Coco Gauff in the third round of the Australian Open, squandering a chance to serve for the match in the former. When the tour resumed, [0] played the Cincinnati Open and the US Open, which were held in back-to-back weeks in New York. [0] did not lose a match at either event. At the Cincinnati Open, [0] defeated four players ranked in the 20s before defaulting in the final against Victoria Azarenka due to a hamstring injury. Both [0] and Victoria Azarenka reached the final again at the US Open, where [0] became the first player to win a US Open women's singles final by coming from a set down since 1994. This was [0]'s second US Open title in three years. Following the US Open, [0] skipped the French Open and ended [0]'s season because of [0]'s lingering hamstring injury.During the Cincinnati Open and the US Open, which were held in back-to-back weeks in New York, [0] drew attention for [0]'s activism. [0] had initially withdrawn from the Cincinnati Open before the semifinal to raise awareness for the police shooting of Jacob Blake, only staying in the Cincinnati Open after they chose to support [0]'s cause by postponing the Cincinnati Open for a day. At the US Open, [0] walked onto the court for [0]'s seven matches wearing a different black mask, each of which with the name of an African American who had been killed in recent years often without significant repercussions.
Professional career.2021: Australian Open title, mental heal: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was seeded third at the 2021 Australian Open. [0] recorded straight-sets wins over Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova, Caroline Garcia, and Ons Jabeur, before defeating Garbiñe Muguruza in three sets in the fourth round despite facing match points during the third set (the only match in which [0] lost a set during the 2021 Australian Open). [0] went on to defeat Hsieh Su-wei in the quarterfinals, Serena Williams in the semifinals, and 22nd seed Jennifer Brady in the final to claim [0]'s second Australian Open title.[0] became one of only three players in the Open Era to win her first four Grand Slam finals, alongside Roger Federer and Monica Seles.[0] returned to the Miami Open as the second seed, making the quarterfinals for the first time. [0] lost the quarterfinals in a shock defeat to Maria Sakkari, winning just four games. As a result, [0] missed out on regaining the No. 1 ranking.[0] was seeded second at the French Open. Shortly before the start of the French Open, [0] announced that [0] would not conduct [0]'s mandatory media assignments. After [0] won [0]'s first match in straight sets and did not hold a press conference, [0] was fined $15,000 and threatened with rising levels of fines and expulsion. The following day, [0] announced [0]'s withdrawal from the French Open, citing mental health issues. Many fellow athletes and sponsors have voiced support for [0], with some noting a rarely discussed issue of mental health, although the overall reaction from the wider tennis community was mixed. On June 17, [0]'s agent announced that [0] would not participate in the upcoming Wimbledon Championships but would take part in the Tokyo Olympics.[0] would later return to action at the Cincinnati Open where [0] was defending finalist. [0] beat Coco Gauff in the second round but was upset by Jil Teichmann in the third round, both in three sets.At the US Open, [0] failed to defend [0]'s title, losing [0]'s composure and the match to the eventual tournament runner-up, Canadian Leylah Fernandez in the third round, despite serving for the match in the second set. During the match, [0] threw [0]'s racket and received a code violation for hitting a ball into the stands. In [0]'s post-match press conference, [0] announced another hiatus from the sport "for a while", revealing that winning did not make [0] happy anymore.
Professional career.2022: Miami Open final: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] returned to competition at the Melbourne Summer Set 1 tournament seeded No. 1 and made the semifinals, before withdrawing due to an abdominal injury. [0]'s next tournament was the Australian Open, where she was seeded 13th and attempting to defend her title. However, [0] was eliminated in the third round by Amanda Anisimova, in three sets. [0] described being happy despite eliminated and discussed steps [0] is taking to improve [0]'s mental health and have "more fun on the court".[0] dropped 71 spots in the WTA rankings to No. 85 following the Australian Open, where she was seeded 13th and attempting to defend her title, with the tournament absences in 2021 contributing to dropped.In March, [0] entered the Indian Wells Open where [0] beat Sloane Stephens in the first round, but lost to Veronika Kudermetova in straight sets in the second. [0] reached [0]'s first final since the Australian Open, where she was seeded 13th and attempting to defend her title after defeating 22nd seed Belinda Bencic in the semifinals. However, [0] lost the final to second seed Iga Świątek, in straight sets.Following a right ankle injury at the Madrid Open, [0] withdrew from the Italian Open. On May 23, [0] lost in the first round of the French Open to Amanda Anisimova.Playing for the first time since the French Open, [0] won [0]'s first-round match at San Jose against Zheng Qinwen in three sets, but lost in the next round to Coco Gauff, in straight sets. Against home favorite Danielle Collins, [0] started positive into the US Open but lost the first set in a tiebreak, and [0]'s first-round match in two sets.[0]'s troubles continued at the Pan Pacific Open where as the defending champion [0] withdrew in the second round citing abdominal pain, having played only one game in [0]'s first round match against Daria Gavrilova who retired due to knee injury.
Professional career.2023: Pregnancy and hiatus: [0] is our person to focus on. Days before the Australian Open, [0] announced [0]'s withdrawal from the Australian Open, as [0] was expecting [0]'s first child. [0]'s 2023 season was curtailed due to [0]'s expecting with rapper Cordae. In [0]'s withdrawal message, [0] confirmed with fans that [0] will be back for the Australian Open in 2024.

National representation.Fed Cup: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] made [0]'s Fed Cup debut for Japan in 2017, while Japan was competing in the Asia/Oceania Zone Group I. Japan won all nine of Japan's rubbers to advance out of their round-robin pool. Although [0] won [0]'s singles match in the play-off against Kazakhstan, Japan lost Japan's other two matches and was not able to advance. The following year with [0] absent, Japan was able to defeat Kazakhstan in their round-robin pool to advance to the 2018 World Group II Play-offs. In the 2018 World Group II Play-offs, Japan hosted Great Britain in a usual five rubber tie. At this point, [0] returned to Japan and won [0]'s opening match against Heather Watson. After [0] lost [0] next rubber to Johanna Konta, Kurumi Nara was also able to defeat Heather Watson to set up a decisive doubles match. Japan won a decisive doubles match to earn promotion to World Group II in 2019.
National representation.Hopman Cup: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] made [0]'s Hopman Cup debut in 2018 with Yūichi Sugita. Japan was making Japan's first appearance at Hopman Cup since 2001. Japan were grouped with Switzerland, the United States, and Russia, and lost all three of Japan's ties. [0]'s only match win came in singles against Russian Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova. [0] also had a big highlight in the mixed doubles match against Switzerland when [0] served an ace past Roger Federer.
National representation.Olympics: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] lit the Olympic cauldron during the opening ceremony. Coming into Tokyo Olympics, [0] was ranked 2nd in the world. [0] lost in the 3rd round of Tokyo Olympics to eventual finalist and silver medalist Markéta Vondroušová after two straight set victories.

Playing style: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] is an aggressive baseline player. [0] has excellent raw power, especially on [0]'s forehand and her serve. [0] could hit 160 kilometers per hour (100 mph) forehands at the age of sixteen, and her serve has been clocked at up to 200 kilometers per hour (124 mph), making [0]'s one of the ten fastest servers on record in WTA history. While [0] can use excellent raw power to hit high numbers of winners, [0]'s key to success is to be able to win long rallies. One of the first notable instances in which win proved successful was when [0] made [0]'s first career WTA final at the 2016 Pan Pacific Open.[0] credited improving [0]'s mental approach and cutting down on unforced errors for [0]'s breakthrough season in 2018. At the Wuhan Open towards the end of 2018, [0] noted, "[0] think [0]'s biggest improvement is mental. [0]'s game is more consistent, there are not so many unforced errors.
